label: Press release regarding union activities
description: Press release regarding negotiation activities during the Hospital Worker's Strike and the union's support of the walk-out by union employees of the State Ports Authority.

metadata.label: Transcript
metadata.value:
PRESS RELEASE     TIME:  1:00

The union of LPNs and non-professional workers at the Medical College Hospital has decided
[that] they will not meet with Dr. McCord under the system of grievance meetings he [
proposed]yesterday.

"This is second class citizenship." said Isaiah Bennet [sic], elected representative of 
[the] workers. "This type of meeting means that Dr. McCord will choose which workers
he will meet with, and which workers he will not meet with."

"This type of meeting is nothing new. The workers were able to set up meetings
for grievances any time they wished through HEW before the proposal Dr. McCord made 
yesterday." "We have already had meetings between Dr. MCCord and workers, set up by HEW."

Mr. Bennett said that a demonstration on city hall is planned this Friday.
"We have contacted the mayor, but he has given no reply." "We feel a demonstration
is necessary."

Mr. Bennett also announced that the union of workers at the Medical College has 
gone on record in support of the union of employees at the State Ports Authority,
Who are now on a [walk]-out. "Since we are working for the same employer, the State of
South Carolina, and since we are suffering hardships be cause [sic] of the same state law,
we must be together in this struggle." There is a state law prohibiting union
recognition at state institutions. "We knew this law is biased," said Robert Bateman,
president of the union, ILA 1422A at the State Ports Authority. "The state is
denying these people the right of freedom of speech, the freedom of assembly, and
the right to participate in the union of their choice, "and the right to protest
the deplorable conditions which exist at the State Ports Authority and the Medical
College Hospital." "I further believe," said Mr. Bateman, "that these employees
should have a say-so in the shaping of their own destinies."

"We will not be dictated to by our elected officials," said Mr. Bennett.
